description: Tell Tayinat (ancient Kunulua) is a large site (comprising both a sizeable citadel and a sprawling lower town) located at the northern bend of the Orontes River, ca. 30 km southeast of Antakya (ancient Antioch). Strategically located, this fortified city served as a royal capital for various historically-attested Bronze and Iron Age kingdoms (ca. 3200-600 B.C.). In 738 B.C., the Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III conquered Kunulua (alternately called Kinalua), then the royal city of Syro-Hittite kingdom of Patina, annexed it, and transformed it into an important provincial administrative center. Textual evidence found at the site (e.g., a large tablet inscribed with a copy of Esarhaddon’s Succession Treaty) leaves little doubt that Kunulua should be identified as Tell Tayinat.
details: In Assyrian sources of the first millennium B.C., the city is referred to as Kinalia (reign of Tiglath-pileser III), Kinalua (reign of Shalmaneser III), Kullania (7th century B.C.), Kunalua (reign of Shalmaneser III), Kunalia (reigns of Tiglath-pileser III and Esarhaddon), and Kunulua (reign of Ashurnasirpal II).

locations.title: CIGS location of Tall Ṭa‘iynāt

names.details: Kinalua is mentioned in the inscriptions of the Neo-Assyrian king Shalmaneser III, including the Black Obelisk.
Kullania is attested in 7th-century-B.C. Neo-Assyrian archival texts from Nineveh (legal transactions, administrative records, and royal correspondence).
Kunulua is mentioned in several inscriptions of the Neo-Assyrian king Ashurnasirpal II.

Untersuchungen Zur Indogermanischen Sprach- Und Kulturwissenschaft n.F. 8. Berlin: De Gruyter, 2000. http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/856541920.

names.details: Kunalia is attested in some inscriptions of the Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III and in the Tell Tayinat version of Esarhaddon's Succession Treaty.
Kinalia is mentioned in one inscription of the Neo-Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III.
Kunalua is mentioned in the Black Obelisk inscription of the Neo-Assyrian king Shalmaneser III.
